questions.text: One day after undergoing total knee replacement for advanced degenerative osteoarthritis, a 66-year-old man has progressive lower abdominal pain. The surgery was performed under general anesthesia and the patient was temporarily catheterized for perioperative fluid balance. Several hours after the surgery, the patient began to have decreasing voiding volumes, nausea, and progressive, dull lower abdominal pain. Medical history is remarkable for Sjögren syndrome. He does not smoke and drinks one to two beers on the weekends. Current medications include pilocarpine eye drops. He appears uncomfortable and is diaphoretic. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/82 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows a pelvic mass extending to the umbilicus. It is dull on percussion and diffusely tender to palpation. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9000/mm3, and platelet count is 230,000/mm3. An attempt to recatheterize the patient transurethrally is unsuccessful. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Several risk factors can contribute to postoperative AUR, including male sex, age > 50 years, joint arthroplasty, and preexisting urinary tract obstruction such as benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), which is the most common cause of bladder outflow obstruction and AUR in older men. An acute inability to micturate can be the initial presentation of BPH.

Since transurethral catheterization was not successful, a suprapubic catheter should be placed for immediate relief of the distended bladder. Following this, the patient should undergo a trial of voiding without a catheter. Furthermore, the outflow obstruction should be evaluated with a uroflowmetry test to quantify the obstruction, and the suitability for treatment options, e.g., with alpha-1 blockers, should be discussed.

B) INCORRECT:

A number of drugs that act on the autonomic system can cause AUR by either decreasing detrusor activity (parasympatholytic agents) or increasing urethral sphincter tone (sympathomimetic agents). Pilocarpine is, however, a direct parasympathomimetic agent that would increase detrusor activity, which facilitates bladder emptying. This patient also takes pilocarpine intraocularly, which makes it highly unlikely that the systemic concentration of the drug would be high enough to have any effect on the bladder.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute prostatitis is usually caused by a bacterial infection of the urinary tract and may also manifest with AUR. While this patient's history of indwelling catheterization puts him at higher risk for urinary tract infections, acute bacterial prostatitis usually manifests with spiking fevers, chills, and perineal pain. The absence of fever and a normal leukocyte count make acute prostatitis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Urethral stricture is a possible cause of AUR. Iatrogenic manipulation (e.g., injury related to transurethral insertion of an oversized endoscope or catheter placement) is the most common etiology of urethral stricture. While this patient was catheterized transurethrally during surgery, it takes much longer than several hours for scar tissue of a urethral stricture to form. Recurrent urethritis may also cause urethral stricture. Because this patient has no history of previous surgeries requiring catheterization or recurrent urethral infections, urethral stricture is an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Neurogenic lower urinary tract dysfunction (NLUTD) may manifest with AUR and is a common cause of bladder outflow obstruction, especially in young men and women. It results from injury to the central nervous system (e.g., multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, stroke) or the peripheral nerves that supply the bladder (e.g., diabetic neuropathy). Postoperative NLUTD, however, is usually only seen following spinal anesthesia and abdominopelvic surgeries, either of which can cause neural damage resulting in impaired autonomic bladder control; NLUTD is highly unlikely to occur as a sequela of total knee replacement. In addition, an outflow obstruction due to NLUTD would be correctable with recatheterization, which was unsuccessful in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient has postoperative oliguria, lower abdominal pain, and a palpable pelvic mass that is dull on percussion, suggesting bladder distention. In combination, these findings indicate acute urinary retention (AUR).

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of frequent urination. He has to urinate every 1–2 hours during the day and wakes up at least 2–3 times at night to urinate. He also reports that over the last 2 months, he has had difficulty initiating micturition and the urinary stream is weak, with prolonged terminal dribbling. His pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 158/105 mm Hg. Rectal examination shows a smooth, symmetrically enlarged prostate without any tenderness or irregularities. Prostate-specific antigen concentration is 1.1 ng/mL (N < 4) and urinalysis shows no abnormalities. A postvoid ultrasound shows a residual bladder volume of 110 mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bladder catheterization (either transurethral or suprapubic) is indicated in acute urinary retention (AUR), a common complication of BPH. Although this patient presents with features of bladder outflow obstruction due to prostatic enlargement (e.g., poor stream, hesitancy), he does not complain of suprapubic or pelvic pain, or a complete inability to pass urine or have a bladder that is palpable on physical examination, all of which are features of AUR.

B) INCORRECT:

Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) is indicated in patients with persistent symptoms despite pharmacotherapy or in patients who develop complications due to BPH, such as acute urinary retention, recurrent urinary tract infections, or hydronephrosis. As this patient presents with a recent onset of symptoms without any history/evidence of complications, another treatment option is more appropriate at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Prostate biopsy is indicated when there is a suspicion of prostate cancer, such as an elevation of serum prostate-specific antigen > 4 ng/ml and/or DRE findings of palpable nodules, indurated segments, and asymmetrical enlargement of the prostate gland. Because prostate biopsy is an invasive procedure and can cause serious complications (e.g., hemorrhage, genitourinary infection, acute urinary retention), it is not routinely performed in patients with prostatic complaints unless there is a strong suspicion for prostate cancer. Since this patient had a normal prostate-specific antigen and his rectal examination was unremarkable, a prostate biopsy is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostatectomy is very rarely indicated in patients with BPH due to the availability of effective pharmacotherapy and minimally invasive surgical procedures for patients who require surgery. In patients with very large prostates (estimated weight > 80–100 g) who are good candidates for surgery, prostatectomy can be a surgical option.

E) CORRECT:

Alpha blockers (e.g., terazosin, tamsulosin, doxazosin) are the first-line pharmacotherapy in most patients with symptomatic BPH and decreased quality of life. Alpha-blockers are smooth muscle relaxants, which decrease the resistance to urinary outflow by causing smooth muscle relaxation of the bladder neck and the urethra, thereby causing a symptomatic improvement in patients with BPH. Alpha-blockers do not reverse prostatic hyperplasia, but they can provide rapid improvement of symptoms.

Orthostatic hypotension (due to vascular smooth muscle relaxation) is a common adverse effect of alpha-blockers. Terazosin and doxazosin are also FDA-approved to treat BPH in patients with concomitant hypertension, like in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Five-alpha-reductase inhibitors like finasteride are recommended as first-line treatment in patients with uncomplicated BPH who have a large prostate, as indicated sonographically (prostate volume > 40 mL) or based on a PSA concentration (> 1.5 ng/mL). Five-alpha-reductase inhibitors prevent the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, which decreases the size of the prostate, causing symptomatic relief, while reducing the risk of acute urinary retention and the need for prostatic surgery. However, symptomatic improvement is seen only after at least 6 months of five-alpha-reductase inhibitor use. Long-term use can cause sexual dysfunction (decreased libido, impotence, ejaculatory dysfunction) and gynecomastia in some patients.

G) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is indicated for the evaluation of hematuria, bladder outlet obstruction, and other voiding symptoms (urinary urgency, frequency, etc). Although this patient presents with urinary frequency and symptoms of bladder outflow obstruction (e.g., hesitancy, weak stream, elevated residual bladder volume), digital rectal examination and ultrasound suggest that the cause of this patient's symptoms is BPH. Cystoscopy is not routinely performed in the evaluation of BPH. If this patient presented with gross or microscopic hematuria, recurrent urinary tract infections, or a history of prior transurethral intervention that might suggest he has a urethral stricture, cystoscopy should be performed.
questions.hint: This patient's urinary frequency and hesitancy in combination with an enlarged, nontender, prostate without any irregularities on digital rectal examination (DRE) and an increased postvoid residual volume suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up evaluation. Eight months ago, he presented with a 6-month history of increased urinary frequency, difficulty to initiate urination, and straining to maintain the urinary stream. Digital rectal examination showed a symmetrically enlarged, nontender prostate with a rubbery texture. Laboratory studies showed a prostate-specific antigen level of 2.1 ng/mL. Abdominal ultrasound showed a post-void residual urine volume of 250 mL and bladder wall thickening. The patient received appropriate treatment. His vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory studies today show a PSA level of 0.9 ng/mL. Which of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antimuscarinic agents such as oxybutynin are used to treat the irritative symptoms of BPH (e.g., urinary urgency and urinary frequency), which are due to detrusor overactivity. By blocking the muscarinic receptors, these agents cause relaxation of the detrusor muscle within the bladder and increase the risk of urinary retention, which explains why they are contraindicated in patients with significant PRV, as seen here. Regardless, antimuscarinic agents have no effect on prostate growth and thus PSA levels.

B) CORRECT:

Five-alpha-reductase inhibitors (5-ARIs) like dutasteride are indicated in patients with BPH who present with evidence of prostate enlargement (> 30 mL on imaging), a palpable prostate enlargement on DRE, and/or PSA > 1.5 ng/mL. These agents prevent the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, decreasing the size of the prostate and providing symptomatic relief as well as reducing the risk of acute urinary retention and the need for prostatic surgery. Patients usually experience symptomatic relief and a reduction in serum PSA (∼ 50% decrease) after 6 months of using 5-ARIs.

PSA levels must be interpreted with the proper correction factor when screening for prostate cancer in patients who have been treated with 5-ARIs because of the associated PSA level decrease.

C) INCORRECT:

Alpha-blockers such as terazosin are the first-line pharmacotherapy in symptomatic patients with moderate to severe BPH. These agents are smooth muscle relaxants that decrease the resistance to urinary outflow by causing smooth muscle relaxation in the bladder neck and the urethra, thereby improving symptoms in patients with BPH. However, alpha-blockers have little to no effect on prostate growth and thus PSA levels.

D) INCORRECT:

The antiandrogen drug flutamide is primarily a component of androgen deprivation therapy for advanced prostate cancer. It is associated with a high risk of toxicity and adverse effects and is not routinely used in the management of BPH.

E) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitors (e.g., tadalafil), which are primarily used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, may also be used to treat mild/moderate BPH with or without erectile dysfunction. Evidence regarding the effectiveness of PDE5 inhibitors is, however, limited. Furthermore, this class of drugs does not have a direct effect on prostate growth and thus PSA levels.
questions.hint: This older patient received treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), as indicated by his original presentation with urinary frequency, hesitancy and straining, digital rectal examination (DRE) findings (enlarged, nontender rubbery prostate), and increased post-void residual volume (PRV). There are several therapy options for BPH, but one agent group in particular can decrease prostate size and, consequently, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of progressively increasing urinary frequency. He feels the urge to urinate every hour or two, which restricts his daily activities and interferes with his sleep. He has no fever, blood in his urine, or burning pain on micturition. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and amlodipine. He does not smoke and drinks 1 to 2 beers daily. His vital signs are within normal limits. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Digital rectal examination shows a nontender, firm, symmetrically enlarged prostate with no nodules. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Several conditions, such as BPH, urinary tract infections (UTIs), malignancy (i.e., prostate cancer, bladder cancer), and diabetes mellitus can cause LUTS. Urinalysis is the first diagnostic step in all patients with LUTS because it can rule out certain etiologies, e.g., pyuria and bacteriuria are typically seen in patients with UTI, whereas glucosuria is typically seen in patients with uncontrolled diabetes. While urinalysis is usually normal in patients with BPH, it may show hematuria due to increased vascularity in the prostate gland; further evaluation is typically required to rule out malignancy in these patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Transrectal prostate ultrasound can be used to assess prostate size and thereby guide the choice of therapy in patients with BPH. However, prostate ultrasound is not routinely recommended to diagnose BPH.

C) INCORRECT:

Prostate biopsy is not routinely conducted to diagnose BPH but is the confirmatory test for clinically suspected prostate cancer (i.e., hard nodular prostate on DRE, persistently elevated serum PSA). The DRE in this patient is not suggestive of prostate cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology is used to diagnose urothelial cancer in patients who present with gross or microscopic hematuria that cannot be explained by other conditions (e.g., UTI, nephritic syndrome, bleeding disorders). However, hematuria is not present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Measuring serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level should be considered in patients with suspected prostate cancer who have a life expectancy of > 10 years and are candidates for treatment. Features that raise suspicion for prostate cancer include complicated LUTS (e.g., hematuria, urinary retention, incontinence) and abnormal DRE findings such as hard nontender nodules, lobar asymmetry, and obliteration of the sulcus, none of which are present in this patient. While PSA levels may also be obtained to aid the selection of pharmacotherapy for BPH in the absence of imaging, it is not routinely recommended in the workup of patients with LUTS and suspected BPH.

F) INCORRECT:

Uroflowmetry is indicated to quantitatively assess for the presence and degree of bladder outlet obstruction in patients with LUTS. Although other conditions that may mimic the symptoms of BPH should be ruled out in this patient, uroflowmetry is generally reserved for unclear cases in which other diagnostic tests have been exhausted.
questions.hint: Irritative lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), such as increased urinary frequency and nocturia, in conjunction with a nontender, firm, symmetrically enlarged prostate with no nodules on digital rectal examination (DRE) in a patient > 50 years of age are most likely caused by benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

questions.text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of urinary hesitancy and poor urinary stream. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, nontender prostate. Serum studies show a prostate-specific antigen concentration of 2 ng/mL (N < 4). Pharmacotherapy with finasteride is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased bladder neck and internal urethral sphincter tone is an effect of tamsulosin and other alpha-1 antagonists, which are also used as first-line agents in the treatment of BPH. Decreased tone results in decreased resistance to urinary outflow, which in turn improves LUTS. However, finasteride treats the symptoms of BPH by another mechanism.

B) CORRECT:

Increased prostatic apoptosis is an effect of finasteride and other 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors (e.g., dutasteride), which inhibit the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT). DHT is the main androgen of prostate growth and the pathogenesis of BPH. Treatment with finasteride results in lower intraprostatic DHT, inhibited prostatic growth, apoptosis, and involution, which can reduce prostate volume by up to 30% in men with BPH and relieve LUTS. 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors also reduce PSA levels by approx. 50%, which must be considered when screening for prostate cancer. They are especially beneficial in men with large prostate volumes but may take > 6 months to become effective. For this reason, alpha-1 antagonists are usually preferred for rapid improvement of symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased production of urine is not an effect of 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors such as finasteride. It is, however, part of the behavioral treatment of BPH in that patients are advised through lifestyle modifications to decrease their urinary volume (e.g., restricting fluid intake before bed and before going out, reducing alcohol and caffeine consumption).

D) INCORRECT:

PDE inhibitors (e.g., tadalafil, sildenafil) act in ED to increase blood flow by inhibiting the degradation of cGMP, leading to smooth muscle relaxation, increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum, and increased penis size during erection. Tadalafil is currently approved for use in the treatment of BPH with comorbid erectile dysfunction (ED), which this patient does not have. The precise mechanism by which tadalafil reduces LUTS in BPH remains unknown, but increased cGMP concentrations in the bladder and prostate smooth muscle are likely to play a role. Finasteride treats the symptoms of BPH by another mechanism.
Image Description:

Exogenous nitrous oxide (NO) activates guanylyl cyclase, resulting in activation of protein kinase G. There is a reduction in intracellular calcium as a result of increased sarcoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase (SERCA) and an increase in myosin-light-chain-phosphatase (MLCP) activity, resulting in smooth muscle relaxation. The net result of both pathways is vasodilation.

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased bladder contractions and reduced muscle spasms of the bladder and urinary tract are effects of anticholinergics such as oxybutynin or tolterodine. These agents work in BPH by antagonizing muscarinic receptors in the smooth muscle of the detrusor. They are used to treat patients with primarily irritative LUTS (e.g., polyuria, nocturia, urgency, and dysuria) and would not be used in this patient with obstructive LUTS because the decreased detrusor tone could exacerbate urinary retention. Finasteride treats the symptoms of BPH by another mechanism.
questions.hint: Finasteride is a 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), the most likely diagnosis in this patient with obstructive lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) and a symmetrically enlarged, nontender prostate.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of difficulty initiating urination. He wakes up at least 3–4 times at night to urinate. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, nontender prostate with a rubbery consistency. Laboratory studies show a prostate-specific antigen level of 2.1 ng/mL (N < 4). Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Hyperplasia of lateral prostatic lobe tissue
Hypertrophy of middle prostatic lobe tissue
Lymphocytic infiltration of anterior prostatic lobe stroma
Infiltrating dysplasia of posterior prostatic lobe epithelium

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Benign prostatic hyperplasia is characterized by hyperplasia of the prostatic glands and stroma in the periurethral zone (lateral and middle lobes). Clinical features include irritative symptoms (nocturia, urgency, and urinary incontinence), obstructive symptoms (decreased urinary stream, hesitancy, and terminal dribbling), and an enlarged, smooth prostate. Prostate-specific antigen is usually normal or slightly elevated due to an increase in gland size.

B) INCORRECT:

Infiltrating neoplasia of bladder urothelium is characteristic of urothelial carcinoma. Although patients can present with irritative and obstructive symptoms, they often have gross hematuria, which is not seen in this patient. Moreover, a symmetrically enlarged prostate with a rubbery consistency would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Hypertrophy describes an increase in the amount of organic tissue due to an increase in cell size. This patient's condition, however, is caused by an increase in the number, not size, of prostatic cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Lymphocytic infiltration of the prostatic stroma is observed in chronic prostatitis, which can manifest with hesitancy, urinary frequency, and a normal PSA as seen in this patient. However, it would classically also cause dysuria and local pain, which are not seen here. Moreover, digital rectal examination would show a tender, swollen prostate.

E) INCORRECT:

An infiltrating dysplasia of posterior lobe epithelium is characteristic of prostate cancer. Although patients can present with urinary frequency, nocturia, and hesitancy, an asymmetric induration or frank nodule would classically be evident on digital rectal examination and elevated prostate-specific antigen would be seen, neither of which is the case here.
questions.hint: This patient would likely benefit from treatment with an alpha-blocker (e.g., tamsulosin).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the physician for a 2-month history of increased urinary frequency. Urodynamic testing shows a urinary flow rate of 11 mL/s (N>15) and a postvoid residual volume of 65 mL (N<50). Prostate-specific antigen level is 3.2 ng/mL (N<4). Treatment with a drug that also increases scalp hair regrowth is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Decreased conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone
Decreased conversion of progesterone to hydroxyprogesterone
Decreased conversion of testosterone to estradiol

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Finasteride and dutasteride are commonly used drugs for BPH that inhibit the enzyme 5α-reductase, which normally converts testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) in both the prostate and hair follicles. DHT is a highly potent androgen which stimulates prostatic hyperplasia and, for unclear reasons, contributes to androgenetic alopecia (male-pattern baldness). 5α-reductase inhibitors decrease prostate size over 6-12 months, thus reducing symptoms of BPH. Finasteride is also licensed for the treatment of androgenetic alopecia.

B) INCORRECT:

Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists (e.g., leuprolide, goserelin) are used in the treatment of prostate cancer but not BPH. When used in a continuous fashion, they downregulate the GnRH receptor, thereby reducing LH and FSH secretion and decreasing testosterone levels. GnRH analogs may cause hair loss due to hypoestrogenism.

C) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (e.g., sildenafil, tadalafil) are primarily used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction and pulmonary hypertension. Tadalafil is also licensed for the treatment of BPH and improves symptoms by regulating smooth muscle tone. However, PDE-5 inhibitors do not affect hair growth.

D) INCORRECT:

Progesterone is converted to 17-hydroxyprogesterone in the adrenal gland by 17α-hydroxylase, which is inhibited by ketoconazole, spironolactone, and abiraterone. Spironolactone is commonly used to treat hirsutism and female pattern baldness. However, none of these drugs are used to treat BPH.

E) INCORRECT:

Alpha-adrenergic receptor antagonists (e.g., tamsulosin, doxazosin, terazosin) are considered first-line treatment for BPH. This class of drugs acts by relaxing smooth muscle in the bladder neck and prostatic urethra, decreasing resistance to urinary outflow without decreasing prostate size. Important side-effects include hypotension and ejaculatory dysfunction. Alpha-1-antagonists do not affect hair growth, however.

F) INCORRECT:

Aromatase inhibitors decrease the conversion of testosterone to estradiol and are used to treat hormone-responsive breast cancers in post-menopausal women. Aromatase inhibitors are not used for BPH and in contrast to the drug here, commonly lead to hair loss due to a relative increase in available dihydrotestosterone.
questions.hint: The patient exhibits symptoms of lower urinary tract obstruction (increased urinary frequency, incomplete voiding), consistent with manifestations of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Side effects of the drug indicated include sexual dysfunction and gynecomastia.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 66 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: African-American, self-identified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I need to go to the bathroom all the time.”
History of Present Illness:


1-year history of frequent urination

urinates every 2–3 hours during the day and wakes up at least 3 times at night to urinate
has had 2 episodes of cystitis treated with antibiotics in the past 4 months

has a weak urinary stream

has not noticed any blood in the urine
does not have any involuntary leakage of urine, pain with urination, or ejaculatory dysfunction

Past Medical History: 


type 2 diabetes mellitus, well-controlled 
nephrolithiasis, treated with percutaneous nephrolithotomy
essential tremor

Medications:

metformin
canagliflozin
propranolol

Allergies:
sulfa drugs
Psychosocial History:

sexually active with his wife; does not use condoms consistently
has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years

drinks one to two glasses of beer weekly

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


37°C(98.6°F)
72/min
16/min
134/81 mm Hg
–

183 cm(6 ft)

105 kg(231 lb)
31 kg/m2



Appearance: no acute distress
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rate and rhythm; normal S1, S2, S4 gallop
Abdominal: overweight; no tenderness, guarding, masses, bruits, or hepatosplenomegaly
Extremities: no joint erythema, edema, or warmth; dorsalis pedis, radial, and femoral pulses intact 
Genitourinary: no lesions or discharge
Rectal: slightly enlarged, smooth, nontender prostate
Neurologic: alert and oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal neurologic deficits


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neurogenic bladder can occur as a complication of diabetic autonomic neuropathy and cause recurrent UTIs as a result of incomplete urinary emptying. However, this patient's diabetes is well-controlled, and diabetic autonomic neuropathy causes a flaccid neurogenic bladder (urinary retention with overflow incontinence) by impairing bladder filling sensation and decreasing sphincter tone. Irregular, small-volume leakage of urine without an urge to void would be expected in this condition. An enlarged prostate in this patient suggests a different diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Bladder calculi, which develop as a result of urinary stasis caused by incomplete emptying of the bladder, can cause increased urinary frequency and a weak urinary stream. However, they most commonly cause painless hematuria, dysuria, or abdominal pain, none of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, this condition does not cause an enlarged prostate.

C) INCORRECT:

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that promotes renal glucose excretion and causes osmotic diuresis. Although its adverse effects include polyuria and an increased rate of UTIs, it does not result in voiding lower urinary tract symptoms. Propranolol and metformin are not typically associated with lower urinary tract symptoms. An enlarged prostate in this patient suggests a different diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute prostatitis can manifest with irritative and obstructive urinary tract symptoms, including frequency, nocturia, and a weak urinary stream. Rectal examination may reveal an enlarged prostate. However, the prostate is usually extremely tender on palpation. In addition, acute prostatitis typically manifests with systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, dysuria, and pelvic or perineal pain, none of which is seen in this patient. Moreover, this patient's 1-year history of urinary symptoms suggests a condition that has a more insidious course.

E) INCORRECT:

Prostate cancer is a malignancy that is more common among African-Americans and results in an enlarged prostate. However, it typically manifests with a nodular, not smooth, prostate. In addition, prostate cancer is generally slow-growing and most commonly located in the periphery of the prostate, not close to the urethra. Symptoms of urethral compression (e.g., weak stream), therefore, typically only occur in patients with advanced disease. This patient does not have manifestations of advanced prostate cancer (e.g., fatigue, weight loss, hematuria, bone pain from metastatic disease).

F) INCORRECT:

Urethral strictures can cause a weak urinary stream and recurrent UTIs. However, this condition is not typically associated with urinary frequency or nocturia and does not result in an enlarged prostate. In addition, most patients with urethral strictures have a history of prior urethral instrumentation and/or urogenital trauma. This patient had a urologic procedure (nephrolithotomy), but it was conducted via a percutaneous approach.

G) CORRECT:

Uncomplicated lower urinary tract symptoms in addition to an enlarged prostate on physical examination are typical clinical features of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), a common condition that affects a majority of men > 60 years of age in the US. BPH causes compression of the urethra, which leads to bladder outlet obstruction. Incomplete voiding results in urinary stasis, which predisposes to urinary tract infections. Patients who are suspected of having BPH should receive a urinalysis to evaluate for UTI and hematuria. First-line treatment of BPH consists of behavioral modifications (e.g., restriction of fluid intake before bedtime, avoidance of caffeine and alcohol) and pharmacologic therapy with alpha-blockers (e.g., tamsulosin).
questions.hint: This patient presents with two storage lower urinary tract symptoms (urinary frequency, nocturia) and one voiding lower urinary tract symptom (weak urinary stream). Additional manifestations of this patient's condition include a sensation of incomplete emptying.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man presents to the emergency department with an inability to urinate for the past 6 hours. He complains of pain in the lower abdomen and says he does not have hematuria or dysuria. He has noted decreased urinary flow and increased nocturia during the past several months. His medical history is significant for hypertension treated with lisinopril and hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin.
On physical examination, his blood pressure is 152/96 mm Hg, and he is afebrile. He has marked tenderness to palpation in the suprapubic region without signs of a mass. A digital rectal examination reveals a diffusely enlarged prostate; the median sulcus is not readily palpable. A urinary catheter is placed, and 600 cc of urine drains immediately.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
13.5
13.5–17.5


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
6400
4500–11,000



Creatinine (mg/dL)
2.8
0.8–1.3


His last creatinine level, measured one year ago, was within the reference range.
His urine microscopy today shows <3 red cells per high-power field (reference range, 0–2), 1 to 3 white cells per high-power field (0–2), and 2 to 10 hyaline casts per low-power field (0–5).
What is the most appropriate next step in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Obtain CT of the pelvis without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The prostate-specific antigen level is likely to be elevated in men who have acute urinary retention; therefore, its measurement is not helpful in discerning the etiology of the acute urinary retention.

B) INCORRECT:

CT of the pelvis may be indicated in an individual with a suspected mass but would not be routinely performed in all patients.

C) INCORRECT:

Urodynamic studies are appropriate to evaluate bladder contractions and urinary flow but can be part of a secondary evaluation.

D) CORRECT:

Obstructive uropathy causes symptoms ranging from insidious overflow incontinence to overt urinary retention. Acute urinary retention is one of the most common urologic emergencies and is frequently attributable to benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Common precipitants of acute urinary retention include medications with anticholinergic properties (including over-the-counter medications such as diphenhydramine), over-the-counter cold and dietary medications (a sympathomimetic agonist may cause bladder outlet obstruction due to muscle-constricting effects on the bladder neck), constipation, infrequent voiding (in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia), prostatitis, spinal or epidural anesthesia, opioid use, and excessive fluid administration.

Key components of the examination of a patient with acute urinary retention include a lower abdominal examination for palpation of a suprapubic mass, inspection and palpation of the genitalia, and a rectal examination to evaluate for masses, impacted stool, the size and consistency of the prostate, and anal sphincter tone.

After other causes of acute urinary retention are eliminated based on a thorough history and physical examination, alpha-blockers, such as tamsulosin, are generally viewed as first-line therapy for men with significant obstructive urinary symptoms and findings of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Initiation of an alpha-blocker upon presentation increases the proportion of patients with acute urinary retention who have a successful voiding trial at urology follow-up to over 60%, thereby obviating the need for immediate surgical intervention.

Key learning point: When treating a patient with acute urinary retention, the next step after a digital rectal examination and placement of a urinary catheter is initiation of tamsulosin.

E) INCORRECT:

Finasteride may be used to reduce the risk of symptomatic progression of benign prostatic hyperplasia, but given its slow onset of action, it would not be appropriate for a patient with acute urinary retention.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man with no medical complaints presents for a general physical examination. During a review of systems, the patient reports hesitancy in initiating micturition and a weak stream; he denies nocturia, incontinence, or dysuria. He is not taking any medications.
The patient is a slim older man with a blood pressure of 123/55 mm Hg and a heart rate of 65 beats per minute. His rectal tone is normal, and his prostate gland is moderately enlarged and firm.
On laboratory testing, his serum creatinine level is 0.7 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3), and his prostate specific antigen level is 0.8 ng/mL (0.0–4.0). Urinalysis with microscopy is normal. A postvoid ultrasound scan of the bladder reveals a residual volume of 50 mL (normal residual, <100 mL).
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A urology referral is recommended when patients have significant symptoms in addition to an elevated prostate-specific antigen level, hematuria, recurrent urinary tract infections, or impaired renal function from an obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Finasteride, a 5α-reductase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of testosterone to its active metabolite, is indicated for patients with moderate-to-severe symptoms, particularly if they have substantial enlargement of the prostate.

C) INCORRECT:

When symptoms become bothersome, the most appropriate initial treatment is an alpha-adrenergic-receptor blocker, such as tamsulosin.

D) INCORRECT:

Tadalafil is the only phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor that has been approved for benign prostatic hyperplasia, but it is indicated only for patients with bothersome symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Benign prostatic hyperplasia commonly causes lower urinary tract symptoms in older men and affects approximately 80% of octogenarians. When a patient has mild symptoms and no complications of chronic urinary retention (e.g., urinary tract infections, bladder stones, or kidney injury), the most appropriate management is observation with annual monitoring of symptoms.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management of a patient with mild lower urinary tract symptoms due to uncomplicated benign prostatic hyperplasia is watchful waiting with yearly reassessments.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man with type 2 diabetes is hospitalized and treated for sepsis from a urinary tract infection (UTI). During the past year, he has been treated as an outpatient for three episodes of UTIs. With each episode, he experienced dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and cloudy, foul-smelling urine. For the past 5 years, he has experienced difficulty initiating urination, intermittency of the urinary stream, and dribbling at the end of urination.
Rectal examination reveals a nontender, enlarged prostate gland. A postvoid ultrasound scan of the bladder reveals a residual volume of 300 mL (reference range, <100). A prostate-specific antigen level is 2.2 ng/mL (reference range, 0.0–4.0).
Following recovery from the current infection, which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Referral to urology for consideration of a bladder outlet procedure

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) most likely secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Mild or moderate LUTS can be managed with medication or even watchful waiting, depending on how much the symptoms affect the patient’s quality of life. The main classes of medications used are alpha-blockers, such as tamsulosin, and 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors, such as dutasteride. However, this patient's symptoms are severe — his prostate enlargement has led to incomplete bladder emptying with a significantly elevated residual urine volume, which in turn has caused recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs) and a hospitalization for sepsis. Although tamsulosin would work rapidly to improve bladder emptying and would therefore be a reasonable temporizing measure to improve this patient’s symptoms, it would not address the underlying cause of his symptoms, the enlarged prostate. Dutasteride would reduce the size of the prostate, but this effect would take several months. Long-term medical management is therefore not a safe management option in this case.

The most appropriate management option for a patient with severe LUTS is surgical intervention. Patients with severe LUTS should be referred to a urologist for surgical intervention if they have any of the following: refractory urinary retention secondary to BPH, recurrent UTIs, recurrent bladder stones, or gross hematuria due to BPH. Treatment of the bladder outflow obstruction with a transurethral bladder outlet procedure, such as transurethral resection of the prostate, can address the underlying problem rapidly, before kidney disease ensues. This option should therefore be discussed with this patient.

Key learning point: Benign prostatic hyperplasia complicated by severe lower urinary tract symptoms, such as elevated postvoid residual volumes and recurrent urinary tract infections, is best treated with surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic antibiotic prophylaxis with ciprofloxacin increases the risk for the emergence of resistant organisms and should not be used as first-line treatment because it does not address the underlying cause of the recurrent UTIs.

C) INCORRECT:

Goserelin, a synthetic analogue of luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone, is used to treat prostate cancer.

D) INCORRECT:

Although tamsulosin would work rapidly to improve bladder emptying and would therefore be a reasonable temporizing measure to improve this patient’s symptoms, it would not address the underlying cause of his symptoms, the enlarged prostate. Long-term medical management is therefore not a safe management option in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Dutasteride would reduce the size of the prostate, but this effect would take several months. Long-term medical management is therefore not a safe management option in this case.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man presents for evaluation of urinary frequency that has been gradually increasing for the past 2 years and is associated with urinary urgency and a need to strain in order to void. He currently wakes up two to three times a night to urinate. His medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension for which he takes insulin and lisinopril. He has never smoked cigarettes and exercises regularly.
He is afebrile and has a blood pressure of 128/82 mm Hg and a heart rate of 70 beats per minute. Digital rectal examination reveals normal rectal tone and an enlarged symmetrical prostate with no nodules. The rest of the physical examination, including neurologic examination, is unremarkable.
A serum creatinine concentration, measured 3 months ago, was 0.9 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3). His current prostate-specific antigen level is 2.2 ng/mL (0–4.0).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in evaluating this patient?

choices.text: No further testing at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Renal and bladder ultrasound may be indicated to evaluate a patient with upper urinary tract infection, hematuria, history of urolithiasis, or new-onset renal insufficiency, but it is not indicated in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

The initial workup for a patient who presents with lower urinary tract symptoms should include urinalysis.

C) CORRECT:

Lower urinary tract symptoms in men are typically the result of bladder outlet obstruction due to prostatic enlargement or benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Evaluation of such symptoms should include a detailed history, physical examination (including neurologic and digital rectal examinations), and urinalysis. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing may also be considered, and a chart of urinary frequency and volume may be helpful if polyuria is suspected as the cause of symptoms.

In this case, the patient reports nocturia, urinary urgency, and straining to void. His physical examination does not reveal any red flags for malignancy (such as a palpable bladder, abnormal neurologic examination of the lower limbs, asymmetric prostate contour, or prostatic nodules), and his PSA level is normal. In addition, he has never smoked and is therefore not at increased risk for urothelial carcinoma. The most appropriate next step for this patient, consistent with guidelines from the American Urological Association (AUA), is urinalysis. Although the yield of urinalysis in this setting is low, the test is simple, inexpensive, and noninvasive — and does occasionally lead to diagnoses that might coexist with BPH and complicate its management (e.g., bladder cancer, infection, diabetes).

Urine cytology or intravenous urography might be indicated if there were hematuria or other suggestions of cancer, and urodynamic studies can be helpful in patients who fail initial management. Surgery should not be considered until a patient has failed a trial of medications and/or lifestyle modification.

Key learning point: The initial workup for a man who presents with lower urinary tract symptoms should include a detailed history, thorough physical examination (including neurologic and digital rectal examinations), and urinalysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound-guided transrectal biopsy is not indicated in a patient who has no red flags for malignancy.

E) INCORRECT:

A postvoid residual measurement or other urodynamic test may be indicated for patients who do not respond to initial symptomatic management or for those who may require surgery. This patient does not currently meet any of these criteria, and this testing is considered optional by the AUA.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of frequent urination, needing to urinate every 1–2 hours during the day and waking 2–3 times at night to urinate. Over the last 2 months, he has had difficulty initiating urination, a weak urinary stream, and prolonged dribbling. Rectal examination reveals a smooth, symmetrically enlarged prostate without any tenderness or irregularities. Prostate-specific antigen concentration is 1.1 ng/mL (N < 4) and urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bladder catheterization (either transurethral or suprapubic) is indicated in acute urinary retention (AUR), a common complication of BPH. Although this patient presents with features of bladder outflow obstruction due to prostatic enlargement (e.g., poor stream, hesitancy), he does not complain of suprapubic or pelvic pain, or a complete inability to pass urine or have a bladder that is palpable on physical examination, all of which are features of AUR.

B) INCORRECT:

Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) is indicated in patients with persistent symptoms despite pharmacotherapy or in patients who develop complications due to BPH, such as acute urinary retention, recurrent urinary tract infections, or hydronephrosis. As this patient presents with a recent onset of symptoms without any history/evidence of complications, another treatment option is more appropriate at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Prostate biopsy is indicated when there is a suspicion of prostate cancer, such as an elevation of serum prostate-specific antigen > 4 ng/ml and/or DRE findings of palpable nodules, indurated segments, and asymmetrical enlargement of the prostate gland. Because prostate biopsy is an invasive procedure and can cause serious complications (e.g., hemorrhage, genitourinary infection, acute urinary retention), it is not routinely performed in patients with prostatic complaints unless there is a strong suspicion for prostate cancer. Since this patient had a normal prostate-specific antigen and his rectal examination was unremarkable, a prostate biopsy is not indicated.

D) CORRECT:

Alpha blockers (e.g., terazosin, tamsulosin, doxazosin) are the first-line pharmacotherapy in most patients with symptomatic BPH and decreased quality of life. Alpha-blockers are smooth muscle relaxants, which decrease the resistance to urinary outflow by causing smooth muscle relaxation of the bladder neck and the urethra, thereby causing a symptomatic improvement in patients with BPH. Alpha-blockers do not reverse prostatic hyperplasia, but they can provide rapid improvement of symptoms.

Orthostatic hypotension (due to vascular smooth muscle relaxation) is a common adverse effect of alpha-blockers. Terazosin and doxazosin are also FDA-approved to treat BPH in patients with concomitant hypertension, like in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Cystoscopy is indicated for the evaluation of hematuria, bladder outlet obstruction, and other voiding symptoms (urinary urgency, frequency, etc). Although this patient presents with urinary frequency and symptoms of bladder outflow obstruction (e.g., hesitancy, weak stream, elevated residual bladder volume), digital rectal examination and ultrasound suggest that the cause of this patient's symptoms is BPH. Cystoscopy is not routinely performed in the evaluation of BPH. If this patient presented with gross or microscopic hematuria, recurrent urinary tract infections, or a history of prior transurethral intervention that might suggest he has a urethral stricture, cystoscopy should be performed.
questions.hint: This patient's urinary frequency and hesitancy in combination with an enlarged, nontender, prostate without any irregularities on digital rectal examination (DRE) suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of difficulty initiating urination. He wakes up at least 3–4 times at night to urinate. Digital rectal examination shows a symmetrically enlarged, nontender prostate with a rubbery consistency. Laboratory studies show a prostate-specific antigen level of 2.1 ng/mL (N < 4). Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Benign prostatic hyperplasia is characterized by hyperplasia of the prostatic glands and stroma in the periurethral zone (lateral and middle lobes). Clinical features include irritative symptoms (nocturia, urgency, and urinary incontinence), obstructive symptoms (decreased urinary stream, hesitancy, and terminal dribbling), and an enlarged, smooth prostate. Prostate-specific antigen is usually normal or slightly elevated due to an increase in gland size.

Key learning point: Benign prostatic hyperplasia presents with urinary hesitancy, nocturia, and a symmetrically enlarged, smooth prostate due to hyperplasia of periurethral glands and stroma.

B) INCORRECT:

Urothelial carcinoma is characterized by infiltrating neoplasia of bladder urothelium. Although patients can present with irritative and obstructive symptoms, they often have gross hematuria, which is not seen in this patient. Moreover, a symmetrically enlarged prostate with a rubbery consistency would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic prostatitis can manifest with hesitancy, urinary frequency, and a normal PSA as seen in this patient. However, it would classically also cause dysuria and local pain, which are not seen here. Moreover, digital rectal examination would show a tender, swollen prostate.

D) INCORRECT:

Prostate cancer is characterized by infiltrating dysplasia of the posterior lobe epithelium. Although patients can present with urinary frequency, nocturia, and hesitancy, an asymmetric induration or frank nodule would classically be evident on digital rectal examination and elevated prostate-specific antigen would be seen, neither of which is the case here.
questions.hint: This patient would likely benefit from treatment with an alpha-blocker (e.g., tamsulosin).

questions.text: An 81-year-old man comes to your clinic for a general physical examination. During the review of systems, he reports hesitancy in initiating urination and a weak stream. He does not have nocturia, incontinence, or dysuria. On examination, rectal tone is normal, and the prostate gland is moderately enlarged and firm. Laboratory testing shows a serum creatinine level of 62 μmol/L (49–93) and a prostate specific antigen level of 0.8 μg/L (<3.1). Urinalysis with microscopy is normal. A postvoid bladder ultrasound shows a residual volume of 50 mL (normal <100 mL). Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tadalafil is the only phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor that has been approved for benign prostatic hyperplasia, but it is indicated only for patients with bothersome symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

A urology referral is recommended when patients have significant symptoms in addition to an elevated prostate-specific antigen level, hematuria, recurrent urinary tract infections, or impaired renal function from an obstruction.

C) INCORRECT:

Finasteride, a 5α-reductase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of testosterone to its active metabolite, is indicated for patients with moderate-to-severe symptoms, particularly if they have substantial enlargement of the prostate.

D) INCORRECT:

When symptoms become bothersome, the most appropriate initial treatment is an alpha-adrenergic-receptor blocker, such as tamsulosin.

E) CORRECT:

When a patient has mild symptoms and no complications of chronic urinary retention (e.g., urinary tract infections, bladder stones, or kidney injury), the most appropriate management is observation with annual monitoring of symptoms.

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial management of a patient with mild lower urinary tract symptoms due to uncomplicated benign prostatic hyperplasia is watchful waiting with yearly reassessments.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up. Eight months ago, he presented with a 6-month history of increased urinary frequency, difficulty initiating urination, and straining to maintain his urinary stream. At that time, digital rectal examination revealed a symmetrically enlarged, nontender prostate with a rubbery texture. His prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level was 2.1 μg/L (< 3.1). Abdominal ultrasound showed a post-void residual urine volume of 250 mL and bladder wall thickening. He received appropriate treatment. His vital signs are normal. Today, his PSA level is 0.9 μg/L (< 3.1). Which one of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The antiandrogen drug flutamide is primarily a component of androgen deprivation therapy for advanced prostate cancer. It is associated with a high risk of toxicity and adverse effects and is not routinely used in the management of BPH.

B) INCORRECT:

Alpha-blockers such as terazosin are the first-line pharmacotherapy in symptomatic patients with moderate to severe BPH. These agents are smooth muscle relaxants that decrease the resistance to urinary outflow by causing smooth muscle relaxation in the bladder neck and the urethra, thereby improving symptoms in patients with BPH. However, alpha-blockers have little to no effect on prostate growth and thus PSA levels.

C) CORRECT:

Five-alpha-reductase inhibitors (5-ARIs) like dutasteride are indicated in patients with BPH who present with evidence of prostate enlargement (> 30 mL on imaging), a palpable prostate enlargement on DRE, and/or PSA > 1.5 ng/mL. These agents prevent the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone, decreasing the size of the prostate and providing symptomatic relief as well as reducing the risk of acute urinary retention and the need for prostatic surgery. Patients usually experience symptomatic relief and a reduction in serum PSA (∼ 50% decrease) after 6 months of using 5-ARIs.

PSA levels must be interpreted with the proper correction factor when screening for prostate cancer in patients who have been treated with 5-ARIs because of the associated PSA level decrease.

Key learning point: Five-alpha-reductase inhibitors like dutasteride reduce prostate size and PSA levels in benign prostatic hyperplasia by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone.

D) INCORRECT:

Phosphodiesterase type 5 (PDE5) inhibitors (e.g., tadalafil), which are primarily used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction, may also be used to treat mild/moderate BPH with or without erectile dysfunction. This class of drugs does not, however, have a direct effect on prostate growth and thus PSA levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Antimuscarinic agents such as oxybutynin are used to treat the irritative symptoms of BPH (e.g., urinary urgency and urinary frequency), which are due to detrusor overactivity. By blocking the muscarinic receptors, these agents cause relaxation of the detrusor muscle within the bladder and increase the risk of urinary retention, which explains why they are contraindicated in patients with significant PRV, as seen here. Regardless, antimuscarinic agents have no effect on prostate growth and thus PSA levels.
questions.hint: This older patient received treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), as indicated by his original presentation with urinary frequency, hesitancy and straining, digital rectal examination (DRE) findings (enlarged, nontender rubbery prostate), and increased post-void residual volume (PRV). There are several therapy options for BPH, but one agent group in particular can decrease prostate size and, consequently, prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of progressively increasing urinary frequency. He reports feeling the urge to urinate every hour or two, which limits his daily activities and disrupts his sleep. He denies fever, hematuria, or dysuria. His medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications are metformin and amlodipine. He does not smoke and drinks 1 to 2 beers daily. Vital signs are normal. Abdominal examination is normal. Digital rectal examination reveals a nontender, firm, symmetrically enlarged prostate without nodules. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Uroflowmetry is indicated to quantitatively assess for the presence and degree of bladder outlet obstruction in patients with LUTS. Although other conditions that may mimic the symptoms of BPH should be ruled out in this patient, uroflowmetry is generally reserved for unclear cases in which other diagnostic tests have been exhausted.

B) INCORRECT:

Urine cytology is used to diagnose urothelial cancer in patients who present with gross or microscopic hematuria that cannot be explained by other conditions (e.g., UTI, nephritic syndrome, bleeding disorders). However, hematuria is not present in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Transrectal prostate ultrasound can be used to assess prostate size and thereby guide the choice of therapy in patients with BPH. However, prostate ultrasound is not routinely recommended to diagnose BPH.

D) CORRECT:

Several conditions, such as BPH, urinary tract infections (UTIs), malignancy (i.e., prostate cancer, bladder cancer), and diabetes mellitus can cause LUTS. Urinalysis is the first diagnostic step in all patients with LUTS because it can rule out certain etiologies, e.g., pyuria and bacteriuria are typically seen in patients with UTI, whereas glucosuria is typically seen in patients with uncontrolled diabetes. While urinalysis is usually normal in patients with BPH, it may show hematuria due to increased vascularity in the prostate gland; further evaluation is typically required to rule out malignancy in these patients.

The 2022 Canadian Urological Association (CUA) guidelines also recommend considering serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurement in men with LUTS to exclude prostate cancer (especially in those with a ≥ 10-year life expectancy) and to provide a surrogate estimate of prostate volume for guiding BPH management.

Key learning point: Urinalysis is the initial diagnostic test for lower urinary tract symptoms to help distinguish benign prostatic hyperplasia from other causes such as infection, malignancy, or uncontrolled diabetes.

E) INCORRECT:

Prostate biopsy is not routinely conducted to diagnose BPH but is the confirmatory test for clinically suspected prostate cancer (i.e., hard nodular prostate on DRE, persistently elevated serum PSA). The DRE in this patient is not suggestive of prostate cancer.
questions.hint: Irritative lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), such as increased urinary frequency and nocturia, in conjunction with a nontender, firm, symmetrically enlarged prostate with no nodules on digital rectal examination (DRE) in a patient > 50 years of age are most likely caused by benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of frequent urination, including urinating every 1–2 hours during the day and waking 2–3 times at night to urinate. Over the past 2 months, he has experienced difficulty initiating urination, a weak urinary stream, and prolonged dribbling. On rectal examination, his prostate is smooth, symmetrically enlarged, and non-tender, with no irregularities. Prostate-specific antigen concentration is 1.1 μg/L (< 3.1), and urinalysis is normal.
